properties.text:
• We are Web Apps Developers
  • Passionate About Building Great Products
  • Passionate About Web Technologies
  • Passionate About User eXperience
  • We Love Automation and Testing
  • We Love Good Code

MILLION12 was founded in 2014 by two brothers, who after years of working on different challenging web projects, in different locations, decided to join their efforts and skills to do something they always wanted: their own web-based SaaS products. Originally from Poland, currently we are based in Reading and London, UK.

We are launching Typostrap - online tool for prototyping live, highly interactive websites and apps, backed by modern web Content Management System (WCMS). We believe it is absolutely phenomenal to have prototyping tool with the power and flexibility of CMS system.

Typostrap is based on Foundation and revolutionary TYPO3 Neos CMS. With it you can quickly make multi-page site prototype, sketch complex application and - with possibility to add your own domain, custom CSS and JavaScript - actually ship it, without even visiting your development department!

Visit the typostrap.io to learn more and sign up for private beta!

Flirts with everything around web-development, incl. DevOps, front-end development, business and marketing side. Loves simple aesthetic design, great UX, superb performance and white wine. Currently at Megabuyte.

Absolutely taken by modern web technologies' possibilities and is not afraid to play with them. Passionate about automation, well structured, performant code, ideally written in AngularJS. Likes adrenaline and never refuses to go for a drinks on Friday night. Currently at Tom & Co Ltd.

Eats Docker for breakfast. Lives in Linux and open-source world and even considers moving there permanently. He's working on our cluster cloud infrastructure based on CoreOS. He's also happy husband and sysadmin at International Seismological Centre.
We are based in London and Reading, United Kingdom. If you wish to contact with us, give as a shout at info@m12.io.

TYPO3 Neos projects

M12.Foundation: TYPO3 Neos plugin implementing Zurb Foundation components. Did you sometimes think how cool it'd be to have all Zurb Foundation components available in TYPO3 Neos? Now it's available. We used it to build Typostrap product.

Neos.Plugin.Blog: TYPO3 Neos plugin for blog and/or article system.

site-m12-io: our website (m12.io), fully open-sourced. This is an example how you can build simple website using TYPO3 Neos CMS. Although the website is very simple and contains just a few pages and a blog system, while working on it we tried to discover and incorporate the best practises. From templating, Sass styling, modern package managers and build systems (bower, gulp) through showing how you can wrap everything in Docker container.

Other projects

  • million12/typo3-neos-abstract: Docker image designed to easy build own TYPO3 Neos based projects inside Docker container. Fully customisable, fully documented.
  • million12/typo3-neos: model example of how you can run TYPO3 Neos (default distribution) inside Docker container. Based of course on million12/typo3-neos-abstract image.
  • million12/php-app: Docker image for building any PHP application. Includes nicely tuned Nginx, PHP-FPM, ruby 2.x and npm installed.
© 2014 by MILLION12. All rights reserved.
MILLION12 Ltd is registered in England, number 7654321.

We are absolutely thrilled about what's happening in the CMS world, especially in TYPO3 Neos world and we'll be writing mostly about these things, including DevOps things related to it.

And since some of us are heavily involved in Drupal-based projects, we sometimes will write about it too, compare them, find out where one can fit better then the other etc.
TYPOSTRAP
Online rapid prototyping tool backed by TYPO3 Neos and Zurb Foundation. Build live and truly interactive mock-ups in no time!

• neos.typo3.org
  • learn-neos.com

properties.title: TYPO3 Neos: how to re-compile back-end CSS with sourcemaps
properties.author: Marcin Ryzycki

properties.text: If you developing things for TYPO3 Neos back-end, it's useful to have its CSS with sourcemaps available.
Neos back-end styles are located at Packages/Application/TYPO3.Neos/Resources/Private/Styles - and from there you call compas compile.

properties.title: Required gems:
properties.source: sass 3.3.0.rc.5 # currently latest --pre compass-sourcemaps 0.12.4 # currently latest -pre

properties.text: Add following line to config.rb:
And you're ready to go!

Year 2014 is going to be busy both in Drupal and TYPO3 CMS camps. TYPO3 has just released completely new flagship TYPO3 Neos, beautifully designed and written from the scratch, with content-first approach, focused on author and developer experience (if you haven’t try it yet, you must do!). From Drupal camp, on the horizon we have Drupal 8 (currently alpha) which promises to be revolutionary too. After a nearly 3-years-long affair with Drupal I’m coming back to TYPO3 world (the why is a topic for separate and rather a long post) - therefore it was interesting to look at current stats and trends regarding these two.

TYPO3 CMSDrupalsource
365k / 0.2%707k / 0.4%builtWith.com (Total)
19k / 1%46k / 2.4%builtWith.com (Top Sites)
4 / <0.1%387 / 3.9%Quantcast Top 10k

As you can see, TYPO3 has roughly 50% of what Drupal acquired so far, when it comes to totals. And this is fine - we do not compete here with Wordpress (12m 6.3%) or Joomla (2.7m 1.4%). It’s like with Jaguar cars: they are never going to beat Opel/Vauxhall quantitatively because they aim for something different. What worries me is that TYPO3 has such a small presence in top 10k websites - which in bystander's mind might rise a question ‘Is TYPO3 really that Jaguar’? I believe the one to blame for that achievement is Acquia - Private Equity backed (M) company behind Drupal, co-founded by its creator, which does great marketing for it, supports enterprise clients who use Drupal, offers dedicated hosting, consultation, software, processes and so on. I was using some of these products and they’re truly impressive. TYPO3 doesn’t have such a back up.
Next I looked at Google Trends to see interest trends around these two. Note: I put TYPO3 twice just to get orange colour for TYPO3 which is its brand colour ;-)

properties.caption: Enter caption here
properties.text: It doesn’t look best for TYPO3: shortly after Acquia was founded, TYPO3 lost the lead. But it’s also interesting that overall trend is downside, for both of them.

properties.caption: Enter caption here
properties.text: Germany is a country-mother for TYPO3, where TYPO3 has the biggest presence. While it makes me happy, I’m also a bit unsettled when I see that the gap between them is getting smaller.

properties.caption: Enter caption here
properties.text: As you can see, UK and USA are places where TYPO3 doesn’t have much presence - and these are most mature market for it! Although I was pretty sure in US it looks better… but apparently I was mistaken.

properties.caption: Enter caption here
properties.text: Very interesting spike in China and opposite trend in India.

properties.caption: Enter caption here
properties.text: This one is quite surprising. When I left Poland ~3y ago (which is also the moment when I switched to Drupal), I was pretty sure that there’s no Drupal presence at all and it felt that the TYPO3 community is quite strong. Now I’m not sure.

TYPO3 and Drupal target roughly the same market. But TYPO3 has a lot to catch up to be as equally recognisable and popular as Drupal. It needs a’laTYPO3IA to respond to Acquia strong marketing. It needs more advertising, it needs solutions like dedicated hosting, it needs companies who would offer support to enterprise customers. It needs PaaS and SaaS products based on TYPO3 which would popularise it (vs. e.g. Drupal Gardens). It needs talks and presence on conferences. And it has to be in English - some of us doesn’t speak German.

If my crystal orb is right, at least some of these we’re going to see happening in 2014 and following years. With new TYPO3 CMS 6.x (continuation of 4.x), completely new TYPO3 Neos - notabene both based on the same TYPO3 Flow v.2 framework - we’re in a good shape to change above numbers. And I’m ready to set my hand to the plough and help a little bit with that.

properties.title: I did Vagrant/Chef setup with TYPO3 Neos
properties.author: Marcin Ryzycki

properties.text: I have perpetrated TYPO3 Neos and/or TYPO3 Flow virtual machine setup based on Vagrant and Chef automation.

UPDATE 2014'09: After playing more with Chef and Docker, ultimately I have moved to Docker as it's far more suitable for application encapsulation and isolation. See million12/typo3-neos Docker image. It doesn't mean Chef is not useful, it still has its place in server/VM provisioning (which can host your Docker services).

I know that plenty of you guys are using Vagrant for web development. My intention was to have TYPO3 Flow/Neos setup, up & running in no time, even for 1st-timers with Flow/Neos and/or Vagrant.

It has Nginx / PHP-FPM / MySQL / phpMyAdmin plus all necessary tuning (e.g. memory_limit for PHP, client_max_body_size for Nginx, Opcode for PHP, MySQL optimisation including correct character-set and collaton settings, etc etc) - so Flow/Neos can run smoothly and fast.

I plan to maintain it as I'm extremely excited about Neos and I'm starting my first serious project(s) based on it.

Have a try - any suggestions more then welcomed: https://github.com/ryzy/vc-typo3-neos. There's a nice README, so just follow the instructions from there.
